Sounds cool! 

I'm on board for this!

I actually agree with you mostly because it would be a great game mechanic, but here is a devil's advocate for the current setup:

The reason healing harms is because healing someone who is dead makes them alive, which means healing undead makes them unalive, or dead. Poison, however, works in the real world by paralyzing tissue, especially muscles and lungs. Seeing as skeletons have neither, they should remain unaffected. If we were to apply poison to zombies, however, in keeping with reality, they'd just become paralyzed, which is simply a confusing mechanic to non-scientists.

By disguising themselves as friendly and neutral mobs, I feel maybe they should also have a faintly different sound to the original mob. For example, they could disguise themselves as a.. Cow. Instead of making the same noise you hear from cows regularly, the imp's sound is slightly out of pitch. That way you can tell when a mob is an imp, but only when you're paying attention?

For the item(s) they drop, maybe they would have a chance to drop an enchanted iron sword (or "dagger") with good, but not great enchantments. If you were to make them thieves, maybe they could also have a chance to drop minerals from coal to diamond as well? Diamond being the rarest drop (except for the iron "dagger")?

The imp is a thieving mob, who is interested in the player‚Äôs food more than causing the player harm. It would be fast like an ocelot. This small one block tall mob would wander around the nether alone, but when the player is within sight would run up and strike the player dealing little to no damage, but any food items located in the players hot bar would be taken. Items in the inventory would be safe.

                After obtaining what it wants it would retreat to areas of safety, such as into lakes of lava. It should take no fall damage, allowing it to jump from high cliffs to avoid being killed. It would also quickly begin to consume any food it takes, gaining any potential effects.  If the player is able to kill it before it consumes all the food, the player will retrieve any food which has not been eaten.

                The imp would be about the side of a baby zombie pigman.  It would be camouflaged so as to be difficult to identify unless the player is paying attention.

                Food is a resource the player usually keeps at the ready to heal; losing the food to this creature would make the nether even more dangerous.

The drop should also be whatever they stole from you, and they should run away from you with a laughter when they succeeded in stealing something xD

I love the idea of torches being dropped, but I think that there should be a chance for more to drop than simply half a stack. I also think that there should be some rarer drops like enchanted diamond pickaxes, golden apples, and the like, though both of these items should be really rare. Water buckets would also be a good idea for the loot table as an uncommon drop as they are used a lot for scaling caves.

Maybe mice could spawn in villages, and rats could spawn in caves. Cats could hunt mice, and players could catch/kill mice to tame cats along with/instead of fish. This would be especially useful if you spawn in the middle of a huge desert with no rivers or oceans around to catch fish in, but you find villages.

My ideas are: Crystal Crasher (a huge purple-blue bird that can be tamed with 1 Totem of Undying that lives under ground in mineshafts), Freaky Fury (a small skeleton bird that is hostile and spawns at night, drops a new item called the Death Staff that when used insta-kills enemies and players and deals 2 hearts of dmg), Dreadrax (a GIANT bird with one eye that is very rare. It is red and dark purple and has markings carved on it's underside) and finally (my favorite), the Draconian Fire-bird (a bird that has dragon wings and breathes fire at the player. Can be tamed and ridden with death staff (see Freaky Fury) . Hit it with the staff to tame it then it can do tricks and carry items the player does not need).

There aren't any birds in the game except parrots so, I think there should be more birds relevant to each biome. For example, there could be Pelicans in the ocean and island biomes or, there could be Toucans in the jungle. Adding birds would make Minecraft more realistic and fun. There could be made - up birds or there could be real birds such as, Peacocks for a real bird and a Phoenix for a mythical and made- up bird. I hope you agree with me about adding more types of birds to Minecraft.

Yes! Add Elephants! üêò
Elephant. We love to have  them in game

Minecraft is not just a game with the purpose to entertain people and make money. The game gave itself the responsibility to make the world a better place. Best examples of this were the implementations of dolphins, bees and pandas with whom they wanted to make the people aware of their high mortality rate.

Mojang understandably has been very hesitant with adding them because of the fact they get hunted down for their ivory, meat, skin and bones day by day. And that is something Mojang rightfully does not want to promote in the game.

But now begs the question: How to correctly add elephants to Minecraft? Let me show you my ideas, which try to emphasize the current situation as well as keep the fictional aspect of being part of a game. [1/3]

Elephant types:

  • African Elephant
    • Spawn in herds up to five (one of them is the matriarch) in the Savanna (other Savanna variations excluded), rarely with tusks
    • Bigger than the Asian equivalent
  • Asian Elephant
    • Spawn in herds up to three (one of them is the matriarch) in the Jungle Edge (other Jungle variations excluded), never with tusks
    • Smaller than the African equivalent

General behavior:

  • Passive and slow
  • Become hostile and fast after being approached too much or a cub is attacked
  • Occasionally trumpet
  • Eat leaves as well as tall grass and large fern
  • Unique animations for picking and eating their food
  • Randomly get saplings by eating, plant them by travelling around

 

Drop:

  • African elephant: Acacia or Baobab sapling
  • Asian elephant: Jungle tree sapling

Breeding:

  • Cannot be bread manually by players

[2/3]

Taming:

  • After a successful pillager raid (can be seen as poachers) in the Savanna, the matriarch of the herd can be tamed by feeding him haybales.
    • After being tamed, the rest of the herd appoints a new matriarch and moves on
  • Tamed elephants can be equipped with
    • Carpets to give them unique looks (like lamas)
    • A chest to transport items
    • Up to two saddles for two players to ride them
      • Equipment cannot be removed, carpets can be changed
    • If water nearby, tamed elephants occasionally spout water
      • If at the player friend: grants effects ‚ÄúMatriarch‚Äôs Blessing‚Äù which grants Fire Resistance for 30 seconds
      • If at hostile mobs: pushes them back and deals half a heart damage

Other:

  • In the Savanna and Jungle Edge biome, there is a chance that the Wandering Trader sits on an elephant instant of leading two lamas

In my opinion, that is the correct way to add elephants to Minecraft. Special types based on the habitat, cute behavior, no special drops and still a unique way to befriend these lovely creatures. [3/3]

This is a great idea. Minecraft has added bees and soon will add axolotls to raise awareness. The Venus Flytrap would be a perfect plant to add. Maybe they would spawn in a rare swamp variant to show how they are declining in the real world. They could eat spiders, cave spiders, endermites and silverfish, but not bees. When they eat bugs, their mouth closes and it takes 1-5 days to digest. They would not be a mob, but a plant that would grow and have different stages. They would attempt to grow a flower at some point and bees would be able to pollinate from these. If you break the flower, you ca craft it into another flytrap or feed it to bees. The flytrap would start 1x1x1 but would eventually expand other a larger area (3x3?). They cannot injure the player, as in real life, venus flytaps are harmless to people. perhaps they could drop special items with special abilities?
OPed much?

I like the idea of nether moths flying around in the nether and it would be a cute addition, but don't the antennas seem kind of pointless? Think about it, how many times are you near a patch of Glowstone? since they are primarily on the roof of the nether you wouldn't get the advantage all that often unless you bring a block of Glowstone and a silk touch tool.

So here is my slice, either Glowstone appears closer to the ground and becomes more common or the moths drop a different item. in my opinion, they should drop Glowstone dust, this would make a great and balanced way to farm glowstone.

Spawning behaviour would be easy to understand and kind of funny, they are attracted to light after all. so spawn them near light sources in the nether.
Hoglins should be passive when wearing antennas. And Hoglins in general should be somehow friendlier towards the moths.
